reviews:
This is my first Olight and I found the build quality to be excellent, and this light is their lower end at $26 CAD. The clicky tail is one of the nicest and most satisfying to click that I've experienced as well as having a very nice textured rubber tail button. But the button protrudes out making tail standing impossible. It produces 180 lumens on high, but the light turns on first in low mode at 5 Lumens. It is a simple, two mode light with no special modes. 180 is impressive from a single AAA alkaline battery. Not the brightest AAA light in 2019, but still one of the brightest for the cost. The low 5 lumen mode is bright enough for many tasks but can actually be a bit too bright indoors at closer ranges. The beam is a soft, wide, balanced flood good for medium range. The colour on mine is very neutral. This flashlight is great for finding things in the dark outside. It also comes with a two way clip that allows the light to be clipped on hats or other clothing in either direction.

Pros:
+Runs on one of the most common batteries, (AAA) and basic AAA rechargeables
+It makes a great gift especially since it comes with a battery included and runs on common batteries
+Interesting "helix" knurling design that also seems to grip better than standard knurling
+Great quality, and brightness for the price
+Small size and low weight
+Sturdy two-way clip is useful and reliable
+Wide beam make it great for finding things or seeing where you're going

Cons:
-Wide beam doesn't throw as far as a more focused type
-Not designed to use or benefit from higher discharge batteries
-Cannot tail stand
-Small size makes it easier to lose if not clipped
-Only two brightness levels, no special modes like strobe, sos

I also bought the copper version which is a beautiful light and it is the same except the high mode is noticeably brighter, maybe by 30-50 lumens, the springs seem stronger and more springy especially on the tail cap, and it is also quite a bit heavier.

reviews:
OK! I've been reviewing far too many flashlights lately, and this one has quite a few things to recommend it highly. It uses stock AAA batteries (and comes with an alkaline one) meaning you can use your own existing piles of rechargeable AAA batteries. It has a pretty simple and solidly tactile latching press button on the pommel. (I have a nit pick and/or complaint about the 2-mode memory choice later, but physically it is good.) Rugged and useful belt clip is removeable, not welded on or otherwise permanently attached. O-ring inside battery cover for good seal, solid feel, no battery rattle, etc. Both light modes are good, the low is just about right for a quick look in a bedside table, tool or tackle box, without blinding yourself while still giving you the illumination you need, and the high is actually pretty reasonable for a AAA. (Is it 180 lumens? I don't have a measurement, but my gut says it is in the 120-140 range honestly. If you want to illuminate a tree from 100 yards this is not the flashlight for you, anyway.)

Medium-to-high rating for the packaging: Nesting paper/cardboard boxes, the outer is an easy tape cut and tab open, the inner which has a perforated tear strip to get in quickly. Actual paper manual with (minimal) instructions but good diagrams. It gets a "ding" for the inclusion of a plastic spacer in the outer box, and for the use of (well designed, but please use paperboard, people!) plastic to hold the flashlight inside the inner box. Now! I will say that the "spacer" is actually useful and repurposeable. For one, it can hold the belt clip when detached so you won't lose it. But it's also a nice little box for tiny screws, tiny watch batteries, etc. It doesn't appear recyclable, but maybe a little "don't throw me away, I'm useful!" label on it would keep some plastic from our landfills and waterways.

Where it gets a solid "darn it!" from me is the memory/control for the light modes. Again, happy with the modes themselves, both the simple number (2) and the light levels overall for each. And it does have a reasonably good feature to prevent "OH DAMN WHAT IS THAT BRIGHT LIGHT MY EYES" as that the instructions say (and the product does follow) "If it is turned on over 2 seconds after it was switch off, it will go directly to low mode as default again". Just go to the last mode selected, people, and use your good momentary select feature to cycle when I *want* to cycle! how is that hard!) But since this is a MUCH better "oh darn" than "OH DARN THIS LIGHT CAME ON AT 200 LUMENS WHEN I WAS EXPECTED 10" that some other flashlights burn your retinas with, I'm not dinging this light for that choice too terribly much. 4.5 stars, closer to 5, as this is really a hard feature to get right "for everyone" after all, we all have a different preference here based on how we will use the light.

Now, some feature improvement ideas: 1. better memory mode, just use the last mode I had on for more than 2 seconds, instead of resetting to low light mode, and then it's my fault if I overwhelm my night vision. But really that is a hard design choice to make either way while keeping the controls simple. Maybe keep your niche here? 2. Magnetic recharge port integrated into the button (I may or may not have a patent pending design here...) and rechargeable battery inside. 3. No plastic in the packaging please, or at least make it clearer to folks that the outer box spacer is actually useful, "don't throw me away!" labeling? 4. Let me unscrew the lens cap so that in the far-future event that the LED finally dies, I can solder on a new/brighter/more efficient one. Yes, I can cut it open and re-weld it after, but ... I don't really want that hassle.

Cheers, and happy flashlighting.

I don't recommend wasting your $20 on this flashlight.

Worked well for the first couple of months, then it started turning on every other try. A few weeks later, it wouldn't turn on at all. I noticed what seemed to be oxidation on the screw that connects the button to the body of the flashlight, so I cleaned it and it was back to turning on.

A couple of weeks later, I found myself having to click about half a dozen times until it eventually turned on and cleaning up the screw wasn't making any difference. Now it will only work when I press the button all the way down and hold it there; if I release my finger, it turns off — the clicking mechanism seems to be working fine (it's making the same sound it did when I bought this unit).

I have other flashlights —a Maglite from way before the first Cree LED units started showing up, a 2×AA Fenix I bought over a decade ago, and some cheap supermarket ones that are… ok-ish— and none of them ever had any of the problems I've had with this one.

To think that I considered getting this Olight an upgrade from my trusty Fenix… :-/
